docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's social well-being has fallen to its lowest point in almost 25 years, and children and young people are suffering the most, according to an index developed by researchers at Fordham University. Of the six problems concerning Americans younger than 18, four -- child abuse, teen-age suicide, drug abuse and the high school dropout rate -- worsened in 1994, the most recent year covered by the index.

headline.main: 25-Year Low In a Measure Of Well-Being

docs.abstract: Index developed by researchers at Fordham University indicates that nation's social well-being has fallen to its lowest point in almost 25 years, and children and young people are suffering the most; four of six problems concerning Americans younger than 18 worsened in 1994; they are child abuse, teen-age suicide, drug abuse and high school dropout rate (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's social well-being has fallen to its lowest point in almost 25 years, and children and young people are suffering the most, according to an index developed by researchers at Fordham University.    Of the six problems concerning Americans...

docs.lead_paragraph: In his first interview about his health, President Clinton said that it was ''very good,'' that he had never had a serious illness and that he had controlled his three most pesky problems: hoarseness, allergies and weight. Sometimes, however, he misses comments in crowded areas because of a mild hearing loss. Mr. Clinton, who is 50 years old, pledged in the interview, on Saturday, to tell the public if he developed any serious illness while in the White House. From the moment he took office, he has had ready a detailed written plan on how to activate the 25th Amendment if he is ever disabled and Vice President Al Gore needs to assume the duties of President. Mr. Clinton said he did not have a living will or other directive to guide his care if he developed an incapacitating illness, and details of the plan under the 25th Amendment are classified for security reasons. Dr. E. Connie Mariano, the senior White House physician, said the plan covered a variety of potentially disabling medical conditions.

headline.main: Clinton, in Detailed Interview, Calls His Health 'Very Good'

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton gives first interview on his health, saying it is 'very good' and he has controlled his three chronic problems: hoarseness, allergies and weight; says he has never had a serious illness and pledges to tell public if he developed anything serious while in White House; says there is detailed written plan on how to activate 25th Amendment if he is ever disabled and Vice Pres Al Gore needs to assume duties of President; Dr E Connie Mariano, senior White House physician, says she would stake her professional reputation on statement that nothing is being hidden about Clinton's health; Clinton has refused to grant requests since 1992 for interview about his health; he has been under pressure from Bob Dole to give interview; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In his first interview about his health, President Clinton said that it was ''very good,'' that he had never had a serious illness and that he had controlled his three most pesky problems: hoarseness, allergies and weight. Sometimes, however, he...

docs.lead_paragraph: For 20 years, Ralph DeKlotz worked as an engineer for Morrison Knudsen, the fabled construction giant that fell on hard times two years ago. When the company finally filed for bankruptcy last June, Mr. DeKlotz, 50, lost a third of his retirement nest egg because the company stock he owned in his retirement savings plan became virtually worthless. Bad as he felt, Mr. DeKlotz was comforted by the thought that he and the company's top executives were in the same boat.

headline.main: Managers Staying Dry As Corporations Sink

docs.abstract: Second of two articles, Rushing Away from Taxes: the Great Retirement Divide, describes how a bankrupt company's middle managers can lose much of their retirement savings, while company's highest officials keep theirs; at issue are deferred compansation packages offered middle-level managers, which allow postponement of taxes on large amounts of pay; if company suffers financial reverses, it might not honor its promises to pay; growing number of American businesses are offering their executives benefits unavailable to rank and file, while pension options to American workers undergo major changes; workers are increasingly offered only company-sponsored 401(k) plans, which are not protected by Government from investment losses; executives are being offered more generous and inventive compensation plans that can be protected even in worst of times; critics claim executives have diminishing stake in health of whatever plan covers their workers; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a Lilco employee was having marriage problems that interfered with work, he went to the Employee Assistance Program at the utility. After several free sessions with a counselor, he was referred to a marriage counselor for further therapy.
docs.abstract: Dr Joseph Gisondo, president of Long Island chapter of Employee Assistance Program Assn, says Long Island companies are split over mental health benefits; says many companies are not doing enough to meet employees' mental health needs, and many employees are worried about not having enough money and afraid of being dismissed if they acknowledge their problems (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been a roller-coaster year for Ron R., an uninsured 45-year-old with AIDS, a $100,000-a-year medicine bill and no health insurance. Ron depends on the state's AIDS Drug Assistance Program, which pays for prescriptions for under-insured people with AIDS, for the drugs that prolong his life. He was shaken in January when the state, faced with a budget shortfall, cut the number of drugs it paid for to 66 from 195. He began paying for some drugs himself, applying to pharmaceutical companies for others and lobbying state and Federal officials to restore what had been cut. ''I'm still relatively vital, so I could do these things,'' he said. ''But for others it wasn't so easy.''

headline.kicker: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE

docs.abstract: New York State's AIDS Drug Assistance Program, which pays for prescriptions for under-insured people with AIDS, gets some lost funding restored and now covers more drugs; more than 10,000 New Yorkers receive help from the program (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ADAM and Margaret Ksiazak are facing a ritual that is becoming as regular for millions of American workers as the arrival of the new year. The open enrollment period for company benefits is here again. Between now and Dec. 1, workers should study the fine print of their benefits and decide whether to stand pat or make a switch for 1997. And two-career couples must decide what to do about redundant benefits, especially in costly health plans.

headline.main: It's Time To Tune Up Job Benefits

docs.abstract: Two-career couples are under pressure to drop costly redundant health plans; insurers are cracking down on double coverage and some companies are offering workers cash bonuses to drop plans if they are covered under spouses' plans; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans became the country's first managed-care company to set up its own alternative-medicine group, and some of its plans will cover yoga, acupuncture and chiropractors.
docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans has become first of nation's managed-care firms to set up own alternative-medicine group; Nationwide, hit by hurricane claims, will cut back on new policies for houses along coastlines (S)p

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR years, Edward S. Cohn has been reading about the shortage of volunteers in emergency services. He knew about it firsthand as a former ambulance corps member in Teaneck and Waldwick, as well as from his years in the Ramsey Volunteer Fire Department. In 1994, Governor Whitman called a conference to address the needs of the fire service into the 21st century, and Mr. Cohn, who was then fire chief in Ramsey, attended.

headline.main: Foraging for Volunteers in High Schools, Restaurants and Roadsides

docs.abstract: New Jersey runs toll-free phone line to refer volunteers to fire and other emergency services in their communities; former fire chief Edward S Cohn, force behind phone line, has created recruiting video for showing in high schools; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TO the untrained ear, the debate last Sunday night between President Clinton and Bob Dole and the one Wednesday night between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp must have sounded like people reciting gibberish. What they kept saying was so clearly repeated by rote (10 1/2 million new jobs, risky $500 billion tax cut scheme, cut taxes 15 percent across the board, balance the budget, Family and Medical Leave Act) that it was difficult to sort out their actual intentions.

headline.main: In a Debate, It's Themes, Not Facts

docs.abstract: Key themes of televised debates between Presidential candidates Pres Clinton and Bob Dole and between Vice Presidential candidates Vice Pres Al Gore and Jack Kemp discussed; candidates, despite efforts to cast selves as centerists, represent essential views that have long dominated their parties; their stands on factual issues, while seemingly contradictory, are often more subjective than straightforward (M)1
docs.snippet: TO the untrained ear, the debate last Sunday night between President Clinton and Bob Dole and the one Wednesday night between Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp must have sounded like people reciting gibberish.    What they kept saying was so...

docs.lead_paragraph: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the group-benefits operations of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company for $86.7 million. There were rumors earlier this month that the deal was in the works. Wellpoint is a big health maintenance organization based in Woodland Hills, Calif. The Hancock operations provide administrative services to corporations that pay their own health care bills. The unit had revenue last year of $800 million. Wellpoint said it planned to retain all the Hancock unit's 2,950 employees, including about 600 in Boston. Hancock is a mutual insurance company with more than $100 billion in assets under management.

headline.main: WELLPOINT AGREES TO BUY BENEFITS OPERATION

docs.abstract: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc agrees to buy group-benefits operations of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance co for $86.7 million (S)
